text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review John Talbot Finn
John is an electronic music producer
from Spain and this is his debut LP but
the first time I ever ran into him was
last year when he released an EP by the
name of families with a badass gorilla
on the cover and an even more badass
title track that featured Glasser on
vocals really great beats and grooves
throughout I didn't review it and I
actually forgot to include it in my
favorite EPS
of 2011 list because sometimes I just
okay but that's all in the past and now
I have this new album on my plate and I
had high expectations going into this
thing because I liked the material on
that previous EP so much and I gotta say
John delivers now if you listen to this
thing you're just gonna get one track
after another of dance tunes that are
just really sexy
they are groovin but not too hard not
too aggressive a lot of just
experimental and micro house tunes lots
of really straightforward repetitive
beats atmospheric effects slow patient
builds just always looking for different
ways to evolve you know just elements
that a good house album should should
have in my opinion but what I like most
is the variety of sounds and ideas that
John is able to bring to this LP while
kind of sticking to those themes lots of
repetition
lots of smooth
atmospheric sounds this album starts
with what I think is one of the best
opening tracks of this year it really
kind of sets up the dark sexy and silky
sounds that kind of flow throughout this
LP the build on this opening track is
especially subtle I think the most
subtle on this entire LP once it kind of
builds up to its peak the rhythm hits me
so hard I just have to thank evolution
that I have thumbs to snap along I just
want to go there are all these panoramic
jungle sounds surrounding the music and
as the track progresses more percussion
sounds are popping up left and right
it's you know kind of becoming a little
electronic drum circle and I love it and
these heavenly background vocals are in
the mix this really kind of warm round
synthesized bassline it is bliss the
second track hits me with another great
groove and a vocal feature from a singer
who's actually featured on the last
track of this thing too and the singing
takes the inherently sexy sound and just
magnifies it especially when the vocals
just get kind of tightly layered like
multi-tracked on top of each other for
these really kind of quick shots of
chorus those two tracks and and and all
the other best songs on here do kind of
feature that just repetitive
ever-evolving groove formula a lot like
caribou or for Tet or Nicholas jar or
mmm Panther do prints his grooves on
this LP are so great when you get into
them you just get lost in them and for
me it's just easy to forget that I'm
listening to a producer as opposed to a
band order especially since all the
early atmospheric sounds on on the
synthesizers on the samples and the and
the percussion some of which sounds like
is sampled hand percussion it just feels
so live the track last land has these
really kind of pitch shifted vocal
samples and what sounds like either
either a string sample or a synth sample
or a guitar being sampled as well it's a
nice
to the various sounds that the John
throws into this LP around these
evolving beats the track when the pass
becomes the present kind of indulges it
a little bit of nostalgia it drops
another one of these beats but the music
surrounding it just kind of ends up
making this track feel like a song that
could have been dropped either at the
tail end of the 80s or at the beginning
of the 90s to be played in the club and
the track horse has these really
sporadic rhythms in it that really kind
of makes it feel like kind of a footwork
song but the rhythm isn't as loud as it
usually would be in that style of
electronic music it's very very quiet
very understated and kind of dark and
eerie because of it some of the songs on
here are kind of short and don't really
evolve as much as others but still kind
of add an interesting sound to this LP
like the third track which the rhythm on
that song isn't really straight forward
is really repetitive because I feel like
John spends a lot of time on that track
kind of improving the rhythm throughout
the track against these swirling synth
arpeggios that are just running in
circles and kind of speeding up and
slowing down and reversing it gives me a
really kind of woozy feeling and the
eighth track on here kind of feels like
a really lucid poppy synthesizer beat
that I could see an artist like Neon
Indian or Toro y Moi singing over where
this LP really gets kind of dicey for me
is toward the middle the fourth track
has a really great groove but doesn't
really come across with a strong flavor
like a lot of the other songs on here do
it just kind of has this one muddy synth
chord progression and it just doesn't do
all that much for me the song missing
you has a nice groove too but where it
kind of puts me on the fence is with
these vocals these vocals that have been
run through so many effects they're
mutated beyond belief and it ends up
making them sound really kind of odd and
dissonant and glitchy and yet again in a
way it's kind of an interesting sound
how did that sound come about I don't
know I
wondering but then again do I really
love listening to it hmm I'm not sure
but my least favorite track on here is
is definitely the song journeys which
sticks out like a sore thumb not only
because it sounds different than all the
other tracks it's way more upbeat and
fruity has kind of a fruity quality to
it but the vocal feature on that track
not only does a sound like panda bear
but it's not even like a good
impersonation of panda bear it's really
kind of off pitch at a lot of moments in
that song it's not even just the way
this singer is singing it's also the
reverb effects that john chooses to put
on these vocals and how he multi-tracks
them too that makes them sound kind of
just like a leftover piece of
Meriweather post pavilion worship from
2009 2010 aside from a few tracks I'm
not too hot on I thought this helped he
was a great debut for John he does a
fantastic job of highlighting the
importance of a great groove and a nice
slow build in terms of the kinds of
emotions and moods that I'm getting from
these songs this album jumps around a
little bit kind of making for a little
of an inconsistent listen but I still
feel like most of the songs on here are
so well put together I just can't not
celebrate them feeling a strong 7 to a
light 8 on this album loved it thought
it was great
but what do you think of this thing have
you heard it if you have do you like it
do you hate it why and what should I
review next you have any Fantana bean
bread
ooh that's not good
